snp5.7:2.3: This is an abbreviated form of the phrase natthi kiñcī’ti that normally marks the dimension of nothingness.
snp5.7:2.4: Niddesa explains kathāhi as either “doubts” (hence a truncated form of kathaṅkathā), or “talks”; the former is followed by Bodhi, the latter by Norman and Ñāṇadīpa. While “doubts” seems contextually more likely, elsewhere (paṭi)virato is commonly used with speech and never, to my knowledge, with doubt.
snp5.7:6.3: Compare the stock idiom Saṅkhampi na upeti upanidhimpi na upeti kalabhāgampi na upeti at eg. sn20.2:1.7; also snp1.12:3.4.
snp5.7:6.4: Nāmakāya appears only here and in dn15, apparently in the same sense. It means neither nāmarūpa nor manomayakāya, but rather the “group” of “mental phenomena”. In this case it refers to one who is freed based on a formless attainment, for whom the rūpakāya has been formerly abandoned.
